docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Like an army, an endurance racing car crew travels on its stomach. Given the quality of most race track fare, it's no wonder the crews often bellyache about it.
docs.snippet: LEAD: Like an army, an endurance racing car crew travels on its stomach. Given the quality of most race track fare, it's no wonder the crews often bellyache about it....

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the last year, more than a half-dozen Chinese restaurants have opened in southern Westchester, and every one has been commendable in one way or another. This reassuring record is a testimonial not only to the amplitude and authority of the cuisines of China but also to the wide distribution of culinary skills among the Chinese in America. It all derives from the Chinese passion for food, of course. Not even the French and Italians are such natural-bred, analytic, argumentative food critics as the Chinese. And seeing a group of Chinese in a restaurant makes one wonder whether the Chinese ideogram for happiness, which pictures various less appropriate things, ought not rather show a large family at dinner. Whatever the reasons for the bounty, southern Westchester has picked up its chopsticks and enjoyed it. Now Szechuan House, an offshoot of Scarsdale's long-established Szechuan Flower, has opened in an Elmsford shopping center, and we seem to have yet another fairly dependable source for the spicy, complex dishes of Sichuan Province.

docs.lead_paragraph: TRAVELERS heading for Munich should erase from their minds every cliche about German food: the dark beer halls reeking of stale beer, oversized platters of sauerbraten drowning in gravy, floury dumplings that could double as lead sinkers. Modern Munich is another world altogether. At every level -- in elegant Old World dining rooms as well as popular beer halls -- the cuisine is more varied and balanced than one would suppose. The current generation of chefs is among the best Europe has to offer. Bright, enthusiastic and hard-working, they are also not afraid to embrace their own heritage, with inventive twists on dumplings, sausages, cabbage and sauerkraut. And language is rarely a problem here: Almost everyone speaks English, and if menus are not already translated, waiters and sommeliers will eagerly assist. Le Gourmet Otto Koch, a chef who has a virtual empire that includes Le Gourmet, which has one Michelin star, and the more casual Restaurant Schwarzwalder, just downstairs, combines German know-how with a solid knowledge of French technique, resulting in a cuisine that is pure, honest and full of earthy, unmasked flavors.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Versailles palace of France's 17th-century Sun King blazed in full splendor tonight as the leaders of 34 nations took time off to relax with a sumptuous gala of ballet and a feast of lobster and champagne. The palace built by the high- living King Louis XIV was lighted by hundreds of crystal chandeliers as a seemingly endless motorcade of dignitaries drove through its gates. With quasi-regal flourish, President Francois Mitterrand ordered the western highway from Paris to Versailles closed to traffic for over five hours to give untroubled passage to his guests.

keywords.value: HOTTEST DISHES OF THE TARTAR CUISINE (BOOK)

docs.abstract: Alina Simone and Alina Bronsky comment on their books You Must Go and Win and The Hottest Dishes of the Tartar Cuisine; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Alina Simone is a folk-pop singer who lives in Brooklyn. Alina Bronsky is a fast-rising European novelist who lives near Frankfurt, Germany. Both are young, both are of Soviet extraction, and both have books coming out this spring. As far as coincidences go, that's not a stunning one, but it further underscores recent artistic contributions from Soviet diaspora children, a whip-smart group now in their 20s and 30s that includes Regina Spektor, Mila Kunis, Anton Yelchin, the comedian Eugene Mirman (a childhood friend of Simone's), and the writers Gary Shteyngart, Keith Gessen and Sana Krasikov. Simone, whose family left the Soviet Union in 1976, when she was 1, says she can't always identify with this bunch. ''I kind of have this insecurity - I'm not Russian enough,'' she says. '' My friends are pretty much all Americanized. We like to go to Brighton Beach and buy the vodka bottles shaped like Kalashnikovs and get all the food that our grandmothers cooked.''

THE COMPLETE BOOK OF SALADS. Including Favorite Recipes of American and British Personalities and Stars. Compiled by Bebe Daniels and Jill Allgood. 206 pp. New York: Prentice-Hall. $2.95.

docs.abstract: Richardson, A W: The Just a Minute Cookbook
docs.lead_paragraph: NO authors could have had a pleasanter assignment than the American gourmet, James Beard, and the wise Scotsman, Alexander Watts, who seems to prefer a French gigot to Scotch haigis. Together they roamed the restaurants of Paris for seven months, looking from bistro to restaurant-de-luxe for the best that could be had in food and drink.
